latestAction.text: Read the second time. Placed on Senate Legislative Calendar under General Orders. Calendar No. 547.

item.text: Motion to reconsider laid on the table Agreed to without objection.
On agreeing to the resolution Agreed to by the Yeas and Nays: 219 - 209 (Roll no. 475). (text: CR H8323)
Passed/agreed to in House: On agreeing to the resolution Agreed to by the Yeas and Nays: 219 - 209 (Roll no. 475).
On ordering the previous question Agreed to by the Yeas and Nays: 219 - 208 (Roll no. 474). (consideration: CR H8329)
DEBATE - The House resumed consideration of H. Res. 1404.
DEBATE - The House proceeded with one hour of debate on H. Res. 1404.
Considered as privileged matter. (consideration: CR H8323-8330)
Placed on the House Calendar, Calendar No. 139.
Resolution provides for the consideration of the Senate amendment to H. R. 6833 and H.R. 8987, and an hour of debate for each measure. It also provides for a motion to recommit H.R. 6833.
The House Committee on Rules reported an original measure, H. Rept. 117-533, by Mr. McGovern.
The House Committee on Rules reported an original measure, H. Rept. 117-533, by Mr. McGovern.

summary.text: Sets forth the rule for consideration of the Senate amendment to the bill (H.R. 6833) to amend title XXVII of the Public Health Service Act, the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, and the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 to establish requirements with respect to cost-sharing for certain insulin products, and for other purposes; and providing for consideration of the bill (H.R. 8987) to amend the Justice for United States Victims of State Sponsored Terrorism Act to authorize appropriations for catch-up payments from the United States Victims of State Sponsored Terrorism Fund.

dublinCore.dc:rights: Pursuant to Title 17 Section 105 of the United States Code, this file is not subject to copyright protection and is in the public domain.
dublinCore.dc:contributor: Congressional Research Service, Library of Congress
dublinCore.dc:description: This file contains bill summaries and statuses for federal legislation. A bill summary describes the most significant provisions of a piece of legislation and details the effects the legislative text may have on current law and federal programs. Bill summaries are authored by the Congressional Research Service (CRS) of the Library of Congress. As stated in Public Law 91-510 (2 USC 166 (d)(6)), one of the duties of CRS is "to prepare summaries and digests of bills and resolutions of a public general nature introduced in the Senate or House of Representatives". For more information, refer to the User Guide that accompanies this file.
